Some examples to get you started.

Making a Dataset

 1    "template_defaults",
 2    "default_template.csv",
 3)
 4
 5import sys
 6
 7sys.path.append(str(main_folder))
 8
 9import PyQt5
10from PyQt5 import QtWidgets
11import metobs_toolkit
12
13
14# =============================================================================
15# Dataset
16# =============================================================================
17
18# A dataset is a collection of all observational data. Most of the methods are
19# applied directly on a dataset. Always start by initializing a dataset object:
20
21aug_2020_all_vlinders = metobs_toolkit.Dataset()
22
23# All default observationtypes present in the MetObs toolkit can be shown by:
24print(metobs_toolkit.observation_types)
25
26
27# we created an dataset and stored in under the variable 'aug_2020_all_vlinder'.
28# The show function prints out an overview of data in the dataset:
29aug_2020_all_vlinders.show()
30
31# =============================================================================
32# Importing data
33# =============================================================================
34
35# To import data, you must specify where your data (and additional templates) are.
36# All this information is stored in the Settings of a dataset. To get an overview
37# of all the settings:
38aug_2020_all_vlinders.show_settings()
39
40# you can see that the settings contain default values. But there are no default
41# values for where your data is. So you have to update the settings.
42
43
44# Start by updating the settings of your dataset so it knows here the data files are:
45
46
47aug_2020_all_vlinders.update_settings(
48    input_data_file=testdata_file,  # A demo data file, downloaded with brian tool: https://vlinder.ugent.be/vlinderdata/multiple_vlinders.php
49    input_metadata_file=metadata,
50    output_folder="/home/$USER/output/",
51    data_template_file=templatefile,

Extracting a Station

 1
 2# We need to specify the start-moment and end-moment for this period. To do this we need to import the datetime module (base python module)
 3# from datetime import datetime
 4
 5# To get the data it is a simple as:
 6# sept_2022_all_vlinders.import_data_from_database(start_datetime=datetime(2022, 9,1), # 2022/09/01 00:00:00
 7#  end_datetime=datetime(2022,9,2,12,45)) #2022/09/25 12:45:00
 8
 9
10# =============================================================================
11# Analysing one station
12# =============================================================================
13
14# if you are interested in one station, you can extract all the info for that one station from the dataset by:
15
16favorite_station = aug_2020_all_vlinders.get_station(stationname="vlinder02")
17
18# the variable favorite_station now contains all info about that station. If you would like to have the observation in a tabular form (pandas dataframe):
19
20observations = favorite_station.df
21
22print(observations.head())
23

Writing to a file

 1favorite_station.make_plot(obstype="temp")
 2
 3# You can extract attributes from the station:
 4
 5temperature = favorite_station.df["temp"]
 6
 7
 8# =============================================================================
 9# Writing to a file
10# =============================================================================
11
12# to write the dataset to a file, specify an outputfolder first. The data will be written there.
13aug_2020_all_vlinders.update_settings(output_folder=os.getcwd())
14

Physiography information

 1print(aug_2020_all_vlinders.metadf.head())
 2
 3# you can see that there is no LCZ information yet. Als long as the coordinates are present, the lcz can be extracted.
 4
 5
 6# =============================================================================
 7#  Get LCZ
 8# =============================================================================
 9
10# To use the LCZ functions, you need a google develeopers account to make use of google earth engine (gee).
11# Creating first such an account, thans simply use this function to extract the LCZ for all stations in your metadata
12
13lcz_values = aug_2020_all_vlinders.get_lcz()
14
15print(lcz_values)
16# Now the metadata is updated with lcz information for each station in the 'lcz' column:
17print(aug_2020_all_vlinders.metadf.head())
18
19
20# =============================================================================
21# Analysing LCZ
22# =============================================================================
23
24# You can recompute the lcz for all stations by calling the get_lcz function on the metadata.
25
26# To make a geospatial map of the LCZ of all stations:
27aug_2020_all_vlinders.make_geo_plot(obstype="lcz")
28
29# =============================================================================
30# Other physiography
31# =============================================================================
32
33# it is possible to extract the landcover fractions of all stations. This is done
34# by defining a radius in meters to create a circular buffer around each station.
35
36# You can select to aggregate the landcoverclasses to water - pervious and impervious,
37# or set aggregation to false to extract the landcoverclasses as present in the worldcover dataset.
38
39# aggregated
40agg_landcover = aug_2020_all_vlinders.get_landcover(
41    buffer=250, aggregate=True  # in meters
42)
43
44print(agg_landcover)
45
46# (the metadata is updated as well)
47print(aug_2020_all_vlinders.metadf)
48
49
50# one can also extract the elevation for all stations from a DEM dataset. The syntax is the same
51# as for the LCZ
52

Applying Qualitycontrol

  1
  2# =============================================================================
  3#  Import data
  4# =============================================================================
  5
  6
  7# 1. Importing a dataset containing mulitple different stations is a function in the Dataset class. First we need to initiate a Dataset with a name of choise.
  8
  9sept_2022_all_vlinders = metobs_toolkit.Dataset()
 10sept_2022_all_vlinders.update_settings(
 11    input_data_file=testdata_file,  # A demo data file, downloaded with brian tool: https://vlinder.ugent.be/vlinderdata/multiple_vlinders.php
 12    output_folder="/home/$USER/output/",
 13)
 14
 15
 16# ---------------- Importing from CSV file -------------------------------
 17
 18
 19# The dataset is initiated but still empty. Filling it with the data from a csv file is simply done by:
 20
 21sept_2022_all_vlinders.import_data_from_file()  # Rember that you added the input file in the settings object, this file will be used.
 22
 23sept_2022_all_vlinders.coarsen_time_resolution()
 24
 25# =============================================================================
 26# Applying quality control
 27# =============================================================================
 28
 29#  a number of quality control methods are available in the toolkit. We can classify them in two groups:
 30# 1) Quality control for missing/duplicated timestamps
 31
 32# These are automatically performed when the dataset is created
 33
 34# 2) Quality control for bad observations
 35
 36# These are not automatically executed. These checks are performd in a sequence
 37# of specific checks, that are looking for signatures of typically bad observations.
 38# The following checks are available:
 39# Gross value check: a threshold check that observations should be between the thresholds
 40# Persistance check: a check that looks for repetitive observation values (indicating a connection error.)
 41# Spike check: Check if an observation does not change between two timestamps by more than a threshold.
 42# Internal consistency check: Check if the temperature observations are physically valid based on relative humidity observations.
 43
 44# All settings, labels, replacement values are defind in the default settings in /settings_files/qc_settings.py
 45# To inspect (and change) these quality control settings, you can extract them out of the Settings:
 46
 47
 48qc_settings = sept_2022_all_vlinders.settings.qc[
 49    "qc_check_settings"
 50]  # Settings are stored in nested dictionary
 51print(qc_settings)
 52
 53# The settings of the QC checks can be updated using this function:
 54sept_2022_all_vlinders.update_qc_settings(obstype='temp',
 55                                          gross_value_max_value=26.3,
 56                                           persis_time_win_to_check='30T' #30 minutes
 57                                          )
 58
 59
 60# Quality control checks are always applied on the full dataset Using the apply_quality_control method on the dataset.
 61
 62sept_2022_all_vlinders.apply_quality_control(
 63    obstype="temp",  # which observations to check
 64    gross_value=True,  # apply gross_value check?
 65    persistance=True,  # apply persistance check?
 66    step=True,  # apply the step chec?
 67    window_variation=True,  # apply internal consistency check?
 68)
 69
 70# ----- INTERMEZZO ------
 71# quality control methods can also be applied on station level. Be aware that the QC labels are an attribute of the station
 72# and not of the dataset the station belongs to!
 73
 74station = sept_2022_all_vlinders.get_station("vlinder01")
 75
 76station.apply_quality_control()
 77
 78print(station.outliersdf.head())
 79
 80
 81# =============================================================================
 82# Quality control values
 83# =============================================================================
 84
 85# If an observation is flagged as an outlier by a check, the observational value is replaced.
 86# By default the outliers are replaced by Nan-values.
 87
 88# =============================================================================
 89# Quality control labels
 90# =============================================================================
 91
 92# Each check makes a label for each observation. These labels are stored in the dataset.df:
 93
 94print(sept_2022_all_vlinders.df.head())
 95
 96# You can see that there is a specific coloumn for each check-label (and for each observationtype that is checked):
 97print(sept_2022_all_vlinders.df.columns)
 98
 99# The labels:
100#   ok: Observation is not flagged as an outlier
101#   not checked: observation could not be checked (mostly because the observations is already flagged as outlier by a previous check)
102#   **** outlier: labeld as outlier by the **** check
103
104
105# After applying the Quality control each observations (that is checked) has a set of qc-labels.
106# To create One column with the final label (based on the labels for each check), you can call the
107# combine_all_to_obsspace, which will combine observations, outliers gaps and missing timestamps,
108# and add a label column per obstype:
109
110outliers_sept_2022_all_vlinders = sept_2022_all_vlinders.combine_all_to_obsspace()
111
112print(outliers_sept_2022_all_vlinders.head())
113
114# or select a specific observation type using pandas
115print(outliers_sept_2022_all_vlinders.xs('temp', level='obstype'))
116
117# (When writing a dataset to file, there is an attribute 'add_final_labels'. When
118#  True, the final labels are computed and added to the file.)
119
120# =============================================================================
121# Quality control stats
122# =============================================================================
123
124#  Some basic overview statistics are implemented for the quality controll labels.
125#  You can extract the frequency statistics by calling:
126
127# obstype: Get statistics of the QC applied on which observationtype
128# stationnames: Which subset of the dataset to use? If None, statistics are computed over all the stations,
129#               if one stationname is given the stats are computed for that station. You can also give a list of stationnames.
130# make_plot:  If True, an overview of pie-charts per check are made.
131
132# The output is a dataframe with frequency statistics per check PRESENTED IN PERSETNTAGES.
133
134qc_statistics = sept_2022_all_vlinders.get_qc_stats(
135    obstype="temp",
136    stationnames=None,  # or 'station_A' or list of stationnames ['station_A', 'station_B']
137    make_plot=True,
138)
139

Making spatial plots

Making timeseries plots

 1
 2aug_2020_all_vlinders.import_data_from_file()  # Rember that you added the input file in the settings object, this file will be used.
 3
 4
 5# =============================================================================
 6# Timeseries plots
 7# =============================================================================
 8
 9# NOTE: All styling settings are defined in the src/vlinder_toolkit/settings_files/default_formats_settings.py
10
11# plotting the timeseries of all stations can simply be done by
12from datetime import datetime
13
14aug_2020_all_vlinders.make_plot(
15    # specify the names of the stations in a list, or use None to plot them all.
16    stationnames=None,
17    # what obstype to plot (default is 'temp')
18    obstype="temp",
19    # choose how to color the timeseries:
20    #'name' : a specific color per station
21    #'label': a specific color per quality control label
22    colorby="name",
23    # choose a start en endtime for the series (datetime).
24    # Default is None, wich uses all available data
25    starttime=None,
26    endtime=datetime(2022, 9, 5),
27    # specify title, by default a title is created
28    title=None,
29    # Add legend to plot?, by default true
30    legend=True,
31    # Plot observations that are labeld as outliers?
32    show_outliers=True,
33)
34
35
36# To plot timeseries for one station you can use the make_plot function on the station object:
37favorite_station = aug_2020_all_vlinders.get_station(stationname="vlinder02")
38favorite_station.apply_quality_control()
39
40# Possible obstypes to plot:
41# 'temp','radiation_temp','humidity','precip','precip_sum','wind_speed',
42# 'wind_gust','wind_direction','pressure','pressure_at_sea_level'
43
44
45favorite_station.make_plot(
46    obstype="temp", colorby="label", title=None
47)  # if title=None, a title will be generated
48
49# Nan values will be not shown in the plot
50
51# If you want to compair multiple stations by a timeseries you can use the make_plot function on the dataset:
52
53aug_2020_all_vlinders.make_plot(
54    stationnames=["vlinder02", "vlinder05", "vlinder07"],
55    obstype="humidity",
56    title=None,
57    legend=True,

Making spatial plots

 1# If you do not specify a start and endtime, all available timestamps are used.
 2
 3
 4# =============================================================================
 5# Geospatial plots
 6# =============================================================================
 7
 8# geospatial plots can be made for a given moment (datetimeinstance) by
 9# applying the make_geo_plot() on a dataset object:
10
11aug_2020_all_vlinders.make_geo_plot(
12    obstype="temp",
13    timeinstance=datetime(2022, 9, 6),  # 2022/09/06 00:00:00
14    title=None,
15    legend=True,
16    vmin=None,  # value corresponding to the minimum of the colorscheme
17    vmax=None,
18)  # value corresponding to the maximum of the colorscheme
19
20# Notes:
